author: Staff Reporter
text:
Multi-storeyed hospitals that have come up after 2009 should mandatorily have ramps.— File Photo

Recording the submissions made by various government authorities that multi-storeyed hospitals built after 2009 must have ramp facility, the Madras High Court on Monday directed the Medical Council of India (MCI), Chennai Metropolitan Development Authority (CMDA), the State Health Department, Fire and Rescue Service Department and the Chief Commissioner of Persons with Disabilities to sit together and work out a comprehensive viable proposal for providing the facility in the hospitals.

The First Bench headed by Chief Justice S.K. Kaul passed the direction on a PIL petition moved by Jawaharlal Shanmugam who claimed that without ramps patients could not be evacuated from the buildings during emergencies due to natural calamities or man-made disasters.

When the plea came up for hearing, all the authorities concerned said that the multi-storeyed hospitals that have come up after 2009 should mandatorily have ramp facility.

As far as the hospitals that were built before 2009 were concerned, it was submitted that such ramp will be made mandatory subject to the availability of space.

Alternative arrangement

It was agreed that in case of lack of space, alternative arrangements would be thought of. Granting a month’s time to conduct the meeting, the Bench directed that it would be the responsibility of the Principal Secretary, Health Department, to hold the meeting and file an affidavit informing the outcome of the meeting.

The Bench then impleaded the Commissioner for Persons with Disabilities as party to the PIL and posted the matter to April 21.
title: Court directive on ramps in hospitals
